editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
SVch have been the out-goings of our God for his people in this our generation, that none as men, but mu≈øt ≈øay, It is Marvellous in our eyes: And none as Chri≈øtians, but mu≈øt cry out; It is the Lords doing, he hath alwaies been a ready help in time of need, and never did his poor ≈øervants ≈øeek his face in vain, neither did he ever lend a deaf ear to the voice of their weepings. Who can utter the mighty Acts of the Lord? who can ≈øhew forth all his prai≈øes? But I≈ørael doth not know, my people doth not con≈øider, for in the mid≈øt of ≈øuch unequalled and ≈øignal mercies, how great hath been, and is our ingratitude and unfruitfulne≈øs? Verily ≈øuch, that nothing can be greater, but that inexhau≈øted mercy, which hitherto hath not con≈øumed us. Should the Lord ≈øay unto us, as once he did unto Ephraim, Ephraim is joined unto Idols, let him alone. That heavy ≈øentence would be but our de≈øert. As in≈øen≈øibility is our crime, ≈øo it might be too ju≈øtly made our puni≈øhment; for who has been melted by mercies, who has
been broken by judgement? Ah ≈øinful Nation! a people laden with iniquity, a ≈øeed of evill doers, children that are corrupters, they have for≈øaken the Lord, they have provoked the holy one of I≈ørael to anger, they are gone away backward: why ≈øhould ye be ≈øtricken any more? ye will revolt more and more. As the≈øe ≈øad words do Characterize us as fully as they did tho≈øe of Juda to whom they were fir≈øt ≈øpoken; ≈øo if that ≈øad Denuntiation ≈øhould al≈øo be our Doom, we could not yet but acknowledge; the Lord is righteous in all his wayes, and holy in all his works. How deeply have we grieved our good God, in not mourning as we ought, even as one that mourneth for his fir≈øt-born, for that ignorance, profanene≈øs and barrenne≈øs that is ≈øo ripe among≈øt us, even under ≈øuch rich means of knowledge, reformation and grace, in not being ≈øen≈øible under, nor making a ≈øanctified u≈øe of, tho≈øe Rebukes we have of late received; But rather charging ≈øuch mi≈øcarriages upon In≈øtruments, chiefly, if not only, when every Individual hath helped to fill up the mea≈øure of tho≈øe ≈øins after which ≈øuch Iudgements were to follow.
In not improving mercies ≈øo fully as might have been, to his glory, from whom alone they were received.
In the ≈øad neglect and want of Activity, Re≈øolution and Integrity, in Magi≈øtrates and others impowred therein, for the puni≈øhment and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of vice and crying Enormities.
In the abominable Bla≈øphemies vented and ≈øpread of late through the apo≈øta≈øie of, and the abu≈øe of liberty by, many profe≈ø≈øing Religion.

In that little love and tenderne≈øs which is
even among≈øt profe≈ø≈øors them≈øelves towards one another, who whil≈øt they contend for things di≈øputable, lo≈øe that which is certain, even Charity, which is the bond of perfectne≈øs, and without which they become as ≈øounding Bra≈øs, or a tinckling Cimball: To love one another is Chri≈øts new Commandement, nay, the very Badge of his Di≈øciples. By this ≈øhall all men know that you are my Di≈øciples, if you have love one to another, in allowing difference in forms, more power to divide Chri≈øtians, then Agreements in fundamentals has to unite them, one of the dangerou≈øe≈øt and fruitfulle≈øt ≈øeed that hath been ≈øown by the envious one.

In not being truly ≈øen≈øible, that though the Lord in the depths of his wi≈øedome and righteous Iudgement, hath for ≈øome years la≈øt pa≈øt been overturning ≈øeveral Authorities in the≈øe Nations, and hath as it were been pouring them out from ve≈ø≈øel to ve≈ø≈øel: He hath yet been plea≈øed ever ≈øince his people publickly contended for his Truths, ≈øtill to ≈øet up Rulers, who have allowed them the free exerci≈øe & profe≈ø≈øion of them.

In that Athei≈øtical and Luke-warm Spirit, too commonly among≈øt us, whereby not only the form but power of godline≈øs is reproached, and accounted as a vile thing, but al≈øo too many have fallen from their fir≈øt love, and others Laodicean like, e≈øteem them≈øelves rich and to have need of nothing, while≈øt indeed they are wretched, and mi≈øerable, and poor, and blind, and naked, ≈øins which are the highlier aggravated, by being committed in Countreys where the Glorious light of the Go≈øpel ≈øhines cleare≈øt.

In being more di≈ø≈øatisfied that we have not obtained all we aymed at, then thankfull that
we have obtained ≈øo much, as through mercy we now enjoy.

All which, with other the grievous ≈øins of the≈øe three Nations, call aloud upon all the good people in them, to lye Low in the ≈øight of our offended God, and by prayer and humiliation; (a way which in our deepe≈øt di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, we have found both our duty and comfort to tread in) to ≈øeek to appea≈øe his wrath; And that he will for his own Names ≈øake be plea≈øed, to remove whatever accur≈øed thing there is among≈øt us, and that as he is our God, ≈øo we may be his people.
That he will infatuate the Coun≈øels, and defeat the De≈øigns, of all tho≈øe that labour to exalt them≈øelves, again≈øt the intere≈øt of his Son and his People.
That he will be plea≈øed in a mo≈øt e≈øpeciall manner to vouch≈øafe his pre≈øence to tho≈øe who are intru≈øted with the mannagement of the affaires of the≈øe Nations:
That as he is the mighty Councellor in him≈øelf, ≈øo al≈øo that he would appear ≈øuch experimentally unto them.

That he would in all things ≈øpirit them to the work unto which they are called, And give them unitie among≈øt them≈øelves, even the be≈øt Unitie, That of the Spirit, In the be≈øt Bond, That of Peace; That as they are a people abounding in Mercies, ≈øo they may abound in Returns.

And that at la≈øt through the unwearied goodne≈øs of our God, the≈øe three Nations, after ≈øuch memorable revolutions, may be ≈øetled upon the ≈øure foundations of Truth, Mercy & Peace, and his people henceforth, being delivered from their Enemies, may ≈øerve him without fear, in Holine≈øs, and Righteou≈øne≈øs, before him all the dayes of their lives.

It is therefore declared by his Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, and the Parliament of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland, That for the end and purpo≈øes afore≈øaid, They do appoint Thur≈øday being the thirtieth day of October next, for a day of ≈øolemn humiliation and ≈øeeking the face of God, through the Mediation of Chri≈øt, in all places within England, Scotland and Ireland, And do therefore hereby incite, and encourage all ≈øuch who≈øe hearts God ≈øhall per≈øwade and make ≈øen≈øible of their duty, and of the Commonwealths pre≈øent condition; that the day afore≈øaid be ≈øet apart by them for the purpo≈øes afore≈øaid. And all per≈øons what≈øoever, are hereby enjoyned and required, to ab≈øtain from the works of their ordinary calling, and from any recreations, or other things again≈øt the fitting and due ob≈øervation of that day. And all Faires and Markets are hereby prohibited to be kept upon that day, but may be proclaimed to be kept upon the day next en≈øuing. And all Officers of Iu≈øtice are hereby required to cau≈øe due ob≈øervation to be had hereof, And the Mini≈øters and Preachers of the re≈øpective Pari≈øhes and Congregations, are to take notice hereof: For which end, It is Ordered, That Copies of this Declaration be Printed, and ≈øent into the ≈øeveral parts of the three Nations, that the ≈øame may be publi≈øhed accordingly.
